job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros:
I heard great things from my peers working in other departments, but my department head was a nightmare to work with. 

Great learning opportunities and employee benefits!
cons:
HR knew what was going on and chose not to do anything about it. 

There was an air of "I'm so smart so I don't have to be nice to anyone... you're just lucky to be here".

review_title: Good place to work; excellent  transitioning within university for career advancement
pros: The benefits are good. The working hours are flexible with great work/personal life balance. Also, offers several certification programs covered by department for career development.
cons: Limited to the Hyde Park Area in terms of safety and still somewhat sketchy. And commuting can be a headache, particularly in the winter.

review_title: Smart place with a big objective
pros: Great community and integration with academic leaders. Intellectually stimulating environment and mission. Large organization and stable. Ambitious leadership and overall strategy. Lots of opportunity if you're willing to take it. Education benefit for family and yourself is often utilized.
cons: Extremely siloed between various elements of the University. Low pay relative to other options in same space. Large variance between different departments and career paths.

review_title: Great place to work. Friendly, good benefits, relaxed and casual environment.
pros: Great benefits. Starts off with 20 days of PTO (5 of which are personal holidays) in addition to sick leave, tuition benefit, great insurance options.
cons: Depending on department, some burnout and administrative and staff versus faculty vibes. Some faculty can be high and mighty and some staff can be burned out. Pay is not as competitive as private sector.

pros: Staff are nice.  Employment process was fast.  Easy location and employee parking is available.  Boss was professional and so was coworkers.
cons: No easy advancent or promotional opportunities.  Company is so big and the work, hours are not good from you to choose from.

review_title: Great place to work and grow career
pros: Great, very bright people to work with; plenty of room to grow career in research setting; hard work gets recognized and awarded; research is cutting edge; beautiful campus.
cons: Administration/HR processing can be more efficient;  higher-ups can be more down to earth, social and relaxed; in terms of outside environment, there are not many shops/restaurants to choose from around the area.

pros: No matter where you work, you will work with bright minds, strong resources tackling issues for the university. Beautiful campus, rich history and name recognition
cons: leadership and power are segmented amongst departments pretty strongly here. which inevitably leads to weird exceptions to organization-wide rules. Oftentimes interactions with middle management in various departments left me wondering if there is enough psychological therapy offered to employees

review_title: Lots of potential, it is what you make of it
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Chicago, IL
pros: Strong academics and environment that cultivates collaboration, good financial support and excellent facilities, prominent reputation.
cons: Sole focus on academics to the detriment of extracarricular pursuits, high expectations of graduate students, resistant to change under the pretense of tradition.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros:
Stipend is competitive

Research can be top tier depending on group

Research tend to be small and allow you to get personalized attention from adviser
cons:
Unversity seems to not care about student quality of life - they do not provide benefits like a free UPass which all other universities in the area do. 

Core facilities are mid-tier

Health insurance is mediocre and does not include dental and vision

job_title: Residency Program Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Good work-life balance. Benefits are pretty good. The premiums are low. Colleagues are good people. The location of the medical center/university is in the neighborhood of Hyde Park within the City of Chicago, that's a plus in my book. The university offers several parking options as well as there are multiple ways to commute via public transit to and from the university. The name and perceived "prestige" of the institute will carry weight when job hunting.
cons: When I initially took this position, I saw it as a way to move up the ranks in hospital administration. I soon found out that this was no more than a glorified secretarial/admin support role which is not how it was advertised. I stayed in hopes of building my unit up and earning a promotion but none of that occurred because there's no promotional track for professional staff here. My biggest issue here is the lack of professional development. HR and Departments here need to devise a plan on how employees will become promoted and there also needs to be clear objectives to increase salary. My pay does not reflect my skill set, longevity,  education, etc. Salaries here are arbitrarily determined and the increases barely keep up with the cost-of-living year over year. My residents are being paid more than me. Their salaries have increased 5% each year which far surpassed my own and I support them. This particular position is not quite defined so it can be confusing as to whether you are part of the hospital or university which leaves too much room for ambiguity.

review_title: Poor experience may be department specific.
pros: Campus is beautiful.  There are a lot of smart people around.
cons: Research not valued in clinical departments.  There are a lot of smart people around that are thinkers and not doers and a general attitude that U of Chicago is amazing in all aspects. Parking is a nightmare unless you want to pay for the garages, especially in the winter.

job_title: Senior Associate Director in Chicago, IL
pros: The University of Chicago is a great place to work if you are connected to the University.  The University offers great benefits and training programs.
cons: Depending on what department or division that you work for, there is not always enough room for career advancement.  Annual salary increases are not great.

pros: Open working environment with helpful leadership, and much space for flexibility for student workers;  Management easy to talk to and caring. Fair and just policy for international student workers, and not too tedious administrative constraints.
cons: Compensation are generally not as good but on par with average student employments, while the school is always in need of student workers and various kinds opportunities are available year-around.

pros: Great health benefits.  Decent work/life balance.
cons: Managment was fine to good until they brought in a "house cleaner" who hasn't been able to keep a coherent team together since laying of a very high percent of their direct reports. People start and then keep leaving, and any positive perception that Argonne staff had seems to have disappeared.

review_title: Great macro level employer; significant quality variation by unit.
job_title: Director, Alumni Relations and Development in Chicago, IL
pros: Great colleagues and professional development opportunities. Really good benefits. Reasonably flexible work schedule.
cons: Individual department is micromanaged by a horrible boss. Bureaucracy can be excessive and frustrating at times.

review_title: Disconcerning staff - PT Interviewers only in N.M.
pros:
10.50 hourly PT only for Interviewers of Amerispeak Support Speacialist multitasking CSR's Forced to do NIS,  and it's constant mandatory trainings. Also worked Amerispeak, and Support calls. all this 
Just to be a CSR support speacialist Telephone interviewer
cons:
Day to day work is random & chaotic! No help from supervisors, they are rude & unprofessional. They Do not assist interviewers in their needs especially when respondents are on the line. Staff just taunts & ridicule interviewers! Told to read message board and dry erase board that changes hourly. No communication from supervisors to interviewers in Amerispeak!! It is a jail enviroment with staff marching up & down aisles, tapping at your desk or leaning on it. Supervisors taunt and harass Interviewers constantly about study FAQ'S because they cannot help us otherwise. No up keep in break room or bathrooms dirty & full of ants!! Coffee machine never works and full of ants and soap. Refrigerator for supervisors only- Give us a real breaks! 6 minutes an hour is ridiculous. Clocking out for breaks every time is  uncalled for.
Also-
There is:
Weekly monitoring on calls and a short emailed evaluation.
Daily Test calls too from Albuquerque and from chicago supervisors.
I had three of these monitored calls a day at times..very nerve wracking! Unsure why I was singled out this way.
Plus monthly evaluations.
Know your FAQ's on all changing surveys or be written up- 
even if NORC changes their ideas of how they want Telephone Interviewers to represent the company to respondants. These ideas change constantly and they do Not tell interviewers of changes until monitoring and write ups began.. so Beware!

review_title: Beautiful campus, good entry level academic research position.
job_title: Research Specialist I in Chicago, IL
pros: Good amenities, great affordable medical coverage and benefit options. I got lucky with  a kind PI and lab mates. Each lab will vary. There were many high quality projects with lab tech positions available at this university when I was looking.
cons: Academia has low pay, however U of C pays on the higher end of the range.

pros: Flexible hours, often I can decide what hours I will come in, as long as I put in the appropriate amount of work
cons: Unsafe neighborhood, we frequently get email alerts about recent thefts and mugging. Crime generally goes up in summer so even during daytime you don't feel very safe if you're walking to your car (if you are parked off campus)

job_title: Senior Associate Director in Chicago, IL
pros: Exciting challenging atmosphere, good colleagues, fascinating research, nice benefits and vacation, beautiful campus with really great architecture, fantastic library privileges.
cons: The leadership is not necessarily attuned to staff issues, high turnover in some departments and schools leading to difficulties getting projects completed.

pros:
Small research centers provide familial experience and supportive team even within larger organization. Generally innovative and open to new ideas. Very supportive supervisors who advocated for employees
Opportunity to travel
cons:
Bureaucratic environment
Minimal salary growth
Can be a bit confined to Hyde Park
Can generally feel a bit isolated on college campus
Felt micromanaged at times

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Orland Park, IL
pros: The only pro to this place was my department. They were a pleasure to work with and I loved my department!!
cons: Management- let me start by saying that I would’ve been employed here 2 years December 2019 as a medical assistant and I started having trouble with management when I asked my “supervisor” at the time for my hired hours back i asked twice. I worked as the only regular employee at U of C Orland Park campus for a min with temp agency employees. My second email was explaining to her that I wanted 8-430 being that i had seniority the only U of C employee I should’ve been able to get my hours I asked and temp agency employees should’ve gotten hours after me. But, it didn’t go that way and me being 4-5 months pregnant at the time my hours was given I knew once I came back from maternity leave my life was going to be a tab bit different and i wasn’t going to be able to work the hours given. Now my stress level was building up  with everything going on around me and I was having a little complication with my pregnancy. At 6 months of pregnancy in May of 2019 I was having constant contractions that had me in the birthing center at least twice a week to be monitored because my contractions was coming (not Braxton Hicks, actual contractions) more and more, my doctor decided he needed to put me on light duty at work i needed to be off my feet. I took my light duty note to my management and was told they had to discuss it and will come let me know. So, about 15-20 minutes later they came up and ask to talk to me, we went in one of the managers office and that’s when i was told that there was no desk work for me and that i had to start my maternity leave that day. A long story short I started my bed rest/maternity leave that day and actually felt relieved for whatever reason that the contractions stopped and my baby actually didn’t come until 9 days after her due date. So now i am to return to work from having my baby in October. The Friday before the Monday that I was to returned I emailed one of the managers around 11am asking to speak with someone because I haven’t heard from anyone after sending my returning to work note to HR and that I wasn’t going to be able to work past 430 due to my newborn baby. The entire day went pass and around 5pm or maybe later cause i have heard from anyone I decided to email the other manager explaining to her that I emailed the one manager this morning the email below (because i emailed her in the email i had sent the other manager) and would like to speak to either one of you before Monday start date. So round 6pm something the first manager I emailed decides to finally pick up the phone and call me. I answered she spoke and said I tried calling you around 1pm something today and I said that’s funny because you are actually my first phone call today which she was.. She started to say that she got my email and that unfortunately they need me to come back with the hours i left with and I explained to her that was going to be our problem because I’m not going to be able to stay pass 430 and that why I tried to talk to you back in January/February when they was trying to figure out our schedules when I sent her that email. She states that she understood my personal side but there’s a professional aspect that they have to go by but come in the Monday and work 8-430 and her and the other manager once again will talk to me about my hours. So I ended up quitting because when she got to talking about a professional aspect of things when the whole time there was nothing professional they did to ME from the email earlier that year about my hours all the way to me returning to work from maternity leave. Everything was UNPROFESSIONAL even when she said she called me around 1pm what ever happen to leaving me a voicemail like professionals do? She never called me that day until i email that second manager who called, text, or emailed her to contact me. Then a week or 2 after I quit I was told another medical assistant like myself had injured her back and they let her work light duty deck work. At that point I’m ready to put a claim in with EEOC because everything was sounding like discrimination to a pregnant person and they wanted me out of there because that jobs had plenty of paperwork for me to do for at least 3 weeks.. I WOULD NEVER RECOMMEND EMPLOYMENT AT THE ORLAND PARK CAMPUS UNDER THOSE TWO MANAGERS!! THEY ARE VERY UNPROFESSIONAL AND IS IN NEED OF MANAGEMENT 101 especially the one manager that never managed before she got that position!!

review_title: Probably the best post doc in Mathematics
